And so, he twisted the knob and pushed the door forward with all his might.

Everything felt noticeably heavier than before for some reason. There was no sound of the door creaking or any pressure coming from the room that closed.

There was only one thing present inside the room.

An unforgettable sight.

Looking from down to up, Zachary carefully watched the scene before him in horror.

The blood dripping from the feet, the legs floating in the air, the body that was too limp to be alive, and the neck that was tied to the noose.

Someone had hung themselves up.

Their face was devoid of lifeâ€¦ yet it stared down at him with shock.

â€œGAH!!!â€

Zachary screamed as he fell to the ground on his back.

He looked back at the dreadful sight of the corpse, his shaking hands and arms could not support him well to have a good look. He did not want to face that sight. He could hear the sound of his voice shaking as his breathing got heavier.

In all his rush and panic, he stood up and ran awayâ€¦

â€¦never to look back on that sightâ€¦

â€¦locking it away from his mind.

He ran and ran in the endless void.

ã€ŒGet me out of here!ã€

He did not care.

ã€ŒGet me out of here!ã€

He just wanted to run away as quickly as possible.

ã€ŒGet me out of here!ã€

There was nothing after all â€” at least, that was what he believed.

â€œSomeone get me out of here!!!â€ Zachary shouted.

â€¦

â€¦

â€œZach!â€

A sound echoed in his right ear, a familiar feminine voice.

But where was he? How could he reach it?

Before he could answer this question, he felt the weight of something creeping under his armpits, before his body was slowly lifted up. It felt as if someone was pulling him away. An immense pressure broke down on him, yet his body effortlessly pushed against it.

He felt rather lethargic. The void was fading away from his sight.

That was when it clicked with him.

It was still not over.

ã€Œ...yes...ã€

He was not alone this time.

He had her.

And so ended the nightmare of a memory.

â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³

Deep from the seabed and up to the ocean floor in a matter of seconds, Lauren pulled Zachary out of the water.

She could not understand why this had happened.

One moment, Zachary was diving into the water in front of her, and in the next, he did not come back. For a second, she thought he was joking around, but then a second passed, and then the next, and the nextâ€¦ no sign of him, he was just not swimming back.

There was only one conclusion: drowning.

When she came to that realization, she almost froze before she thought of acting quickly to save him.

And just so it happened, she was now carrying his body and pulling him out of the ocean after he had drowned.

Thankfully, they were close to the beach right beside the docks, which served as a safe place to reach for now, and a place they could head back up from.

ã€ŒWe were just having fun. Why did it come to this?ã€

Simply put, she did not account for the other person that was with her. All she cared about was showing off everything that she had experienced and was capable of. It wasnâ€™t to that extent of self-absorption. There was still goodwill in her actions, she merely wanted to share her secret source of joy and passion with someone else and recklessly thought theyâ€™d feel the same.

ã€ŒBut he was smilingâ€¦ he looked happy. Was I too forceful?ã€

Nothing of what she thought mattered now. She had to save Zachary.

Walking up to the shore, she placed Zachary on the sand before lying on her knees next to him. She tried her hardest to think of how to save him.

She knew nothing whatsoever about CPR. There was, of course, the option of running with him to the nearest hospital. But she wasn't going to make it on time considering they were off at the edge of town.

ã€ŒYou gotta do something, Lauren.ã€

Just as she was about to place her hands on his chestâ€¦

His eyes suddenly opened. Following that were a couple of coughs that spilled out the water trapped inside him. He breathed heavily after recovering as he tried to grasp the world around him.

Zachary was back in the world of the living.

â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³

â€œOh thank god!â€ Lauren gasped in relief, â€œAre you okay? Can you see me? What happened down there? Why did you jump if you didn't know how to swim? Why didnâ€™t you stop me? How could you let yourself drown there?â€

Even after escaping the brink of death, there was no escaping the questions. However, the plethora of questions this time were coming from the girl he never expected to see with a panic-stricken face. It was obvious how bad she was in her panicked state. Most of her questions didnâ€™t make sense and were unreasonable to ask.

Coming back to his senses, Zachary noticed that Lauren had both her hands tightly gripping his arms as if she was trying to hold him from running away.

Her eyes were filled to the brim with worry. There was sweat dripping from her side (or maybe it was just from the water). If what he had experienced was just a hallucination, then what could have happened to him in the real world? Whatever happened to him, it must have worried her a great ton.

â€œWhatâ€¦â€ He tried speaking.

After seeing him gradually returning back to consciousness, she shook her head in an attempt to ease her worry.

â€œHey hey, itâ€™s me. Donâ€™t worryâ€¦,â€ her voice was soothing.

Solace gradually seeped into his mind, putting him at rest.

It was as if he was a lost child who was reunited with his parents after some time. In this case, it was a hopeless idiot pulled back into reality by the only one who believed in him, a girl that he had just met the other day, yet felt like he had known her for decades.

â€œWhyâ€¦,â€ her voice still had bizarre cracks in the tone, â€œWhat happened to you?â€

Zachary remembered what happened clearly. But he didnâ€™t want to worry her even more with something that wouldnâ€™t make sense to her.

He tried to laugh it off, â€œHeyâ€¦ I was justâ€¦ taking it all inâ€¦ like you said before.â€

Hearing that awful attempt at a sense of humor eased her distress and made her almost laugh for a second â€” which was exactly what he intended â€” but her eyes were still struck with fret.

ã€ŒWas sheâ€¦ crying?ã€

Before he could dwell on that thought further, she replied to his joke.

â€œI donâ€™tâ€¦ I donâ€™t think that same method applies here,â€ she chuckled.

â€œI guess notâ€¦ Wanna see me try again?â€

â€œOh shut up, this is nothing to joke about.â€

Lauren was irritated by the fact that he was smiling so casually. Yet, she let a chuckle escape her breath. She was laughing about this entire scene. A worrisome idiot tending to a careless idiot that she had just met the other day, both alone on that dusk-coated beach. It was a fact that they both believed: they were idiots.

She sighed, â€œI have a feeling this partnership of ours is going to be quite troublesome.â€

He coughed two times instead of laughing, before clearing his throat to answer her properly. â€œYou donâ€™t say.â€

And just like that, the two were enveloped within a world of their own.

â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³

â€œIf this isnâ€™t an omen, I donâ€™t know what is.â€

â€œItâ€™s called being an idiot.â€ Lauren tried to reassure Zachary.

Despite all the hesitation and thought he was at that moment, he realized that he had still jumped off the lighthouse and into the water fully clothed.

â€œPerhaps I was too reckless.â€

â€œThatâ€™s one way to look at it.â€ Lauren tried to mock him, â€œPerhaps you should carefully look things over before doing something.â€

â€œReally? And what if I fa~~â€ He lowered his head as if he were going to drop dead on the ground.

â€œNo!â€ She reached for his shoulders to pull him back up, â€œDonâ€™t sleep now!â€

â€œBut I wanna sleep so bad, come on,â€ he spoke like a nagging child. He could stomp his legs on the ground and it wouldnâ€™t feel odd with the manner he spoke in.

Lauren sighed, â€œSo you do have a fun sideâ€¦ at awful times. Come on, we should get you home now.â€

â€œOh, weâ€™re here actually!â€

After a few encounters with the military police patrolling the town (to ensure that everyone was acting accordingly), the two rascals were out of the main streets and into neighborhood side streets, away from all the ruckus.

On their left was a metal gate that reached up to almost a two-story building, preceding it was a long path of immaculate concrete tiles surrounded by fields of grass with the lightest color on both sides â€” the rest was barely visible due to how long the path was. Beyond the trees and fields, a mansion sprung up from afar.

â€œOh wow,â€ Lauren was surprised, â€œI didnâ€™t know you lived near a mansion like this! Must feel bad living so close to your dreaâ€”â€

Zachary passed her and went right in the direction of the mansion itself. It didnâ€™t take long before he approached the gate and pushed it open with ease.

â€œWait wait wait waitâ€” You live here?!!â€ She shouted with surprise.

She moved backward in shock while staring at the mansion in all of its entirety. Its sight was something to behold. The number of windows plastered on its front was endless, it was almost close to being a glass house â€” talk about privacy for a â€˜privateâ€™ mansion. Despite the archaic feel to it (like everything in that town), it was rather clean in its presentation with white paint coating its entirety. It could potentially pass off as a modern mansion with an old gothic decoration when in reality, it was over a hundred years old.

A revelation of this magnitude left Lauren in utter awe. She looked at Zachary after getting her fill of the mansionâ€™s image.

Even though he had seen her react in shock, he could feel a moment of scolding rising up.

â€œYouâ€™re mad, arenâ€™t you?â€ He chuckled nervously as he rubbed the back of his head.

â€œOf course Iâ€™m mad!â€ She stomped her feet on the ground like a child throwing a tantrum. â€œYouâ€™re living the high lifeâ€”â€

â€œItâ€™s not all what it looks likeâ€¦ Just flare and no color.â€ He spoke before she could go on. He still bore his apologetic expression yet he wanted to make it clear what type of colorless life he had been led to in this place. He wanted to vent out all the problems he had with this â€œhome,â€ howeverâ€¦ â€œBesides, weâ€™ve only just met.â€

â€œExcuses, excuses,â€ she closed her eyes and waved her arm around in rejection as she approached him, â€œI donâ€™t want any of that, Mister. That should have been the first thing you said when we first met.â€

He raised an eyebrow and thought for a moment. â€œWhat? Should I have just said â€œHey, Iâ€™m rich and I live in a huge mansion that could rival Draculaâ€™sâ€ or something like that?â€

All of a sudden, Lauren sprung up on her feet, grabbed Zacharyâ€™s hand, and held them both up before closing some of the distance between him and her.

Her face lit up with excitement like never before, â€œIâ€™d marry you on the spot!â€

Those words left him shocked and speechless.

For all the bizarre things happening that day, he felt a slight ache in his heart. Seeing Laurenâ€™s face and hearing her words only deepened that ache within him. Why? He would wonder. Because those simple words would make anyone flutter in fantasy. Right about now, he should be dreaming in his little cloud bubble about their wedding together â€” a fantasy fit for the gullible. But he knew better.

â€œBut leave out the Dracula part,â€ she let go of his hands as she turned away.

He chuckled, hiding his dismay. â€œI knew youâ€™d say that.â€

â€œYeah, nothing could beat Draculaâ€™s castle if weâ€™re being honest.â€ She rushed back to Zachary with a, once again, exciting look. â€œI mean, have you seen it, man? It could very much be a castle and a towerâ€¦ and it moves!!!â€

This was all just a jestering matter.

ã€ŒOf course she was only joking.ã€

But after confirming for himself, he felt the ache in his heart slightly fade away. And truth be told, he did not want anything else. He was glad to be able to have a friend to joke with. It was a dream come true, and a step in the right direction.

â€œBy the way,â€ He tried to distract his thoughts, â€œWhat were you going to show me back in the ocean? The thing about freshening up our minds.â€

Lauren thought for a second before it hit her, â€œOh? It was this!â€

She reached for her bag and pulled out a large cold coin to show off to Zachary.

â€œA coinâ€¦ golden coin?â€ He did not get her enthusiasm, â€œThatâ€™s what I almost drowned for? And you had it with you this entire time?â€

â€œN-No, there was more down in the sea, a-and I didnâ€™t you were gonnaâ€¦,â€ she stopped when she finally remembered the purpose of this coin, â€œThis is not just any coin. Itâ€™s a Grail Coin.â€

Instead of replying back to her, he felt lost. He had no idea what she was talking about. It left him with an unfocused gaze of confusion.

â€œWell, they say,â€ she started explaining the story, â€œIn the past, there was a race across the globe for obtaining the legendary â€œHoly Grail.â€ The participants were divided into factions with their own allies. It was said that those who got ahold of its coins were closer to the prize than most. But it wasnâ€™t just any type of Grail Coins, they were supposed to be coins that aligned with their factions. This one bears the sigil of the Hanged Man.â€

She quickly held the coin right in front of Zacharyâ€™s eyes to show its details.

The coin was certainly bigger than any coin he had ever seen before.

It was rusty, most likely from being under the ocean for who knew how long. There was a certain symbol crafted on it, which seemed like a man drawn upside down. Of course, one could always rotate it to make it look upright, but what distinguished that the intended symbol was upside down was the rope at the end of the manâ€™s leg. It was indeedâ€¦ a hanged man.

â€œI hear that it fetches a high price on the market,â€ she smiled wryly.

Zachary tried to grasp what he was hearing, â€œYou dragged me through all that trouble for treasure hunting?â€

â€œNooooo I would never,â€ the way she had said it made it hard to believe, â€œNow, open up your hand.â€

He complied with her command.

She placed the gold coin on top of his palm, â€œClose your eyes.â€

ã€ŒThis again?ã€

Just as before, he shut his eyes.

â€œNow put your other palm on this one.â€

Even though he realized the beauty of such things, he still lacked enthusiasm when it came to the first-time process. Nevertheless, he listened to Laurenâ€™s request.

â€œCan you feel it?â€

â€œF-Feel what? The coin?â€

â€œYes. What else?â€

â€œI guess soâ€¦â€

He was holding it after all. Not feeling the coin on his hand would mean that he could not feel his hand altogether.

â€œTake all its features in like you did before without looking. Just touching.â€

With the coin tightly in his full grasp, he rubbed both his hands against each other, getting himself to â€œfeelâ€ the coin that was in-between in the process.

At first, he felt the inscriptions on the coin, there were some that seemed missing, seeing as there were sharp gaps in the middle. Since there was barely anything at this â€œsmallâ€ coin, compared to the scenery he had to look at earlier that day, he was already feeling the sigil at the center. It was neatly carved, vastly different from the inscriptions, but then something seemed to be missing as well, or ratherâ€¦ it was carved deeper than the rest of the body.

Curious about that last detail, Zachary opened his eyes and palm before taking a good look at the coin. It was the leg wrapped with a rope. Now that he was directly looking at it, he narrowed his eyes to focus.

ã€ŒA button?ã€

â€œAnd thatâ€™s another test done.â€ Lauren clapped her hands.

Zachary flinched for a second.

He had almost forgotten that Lauren was here with him. Perhaps that was one of the points she tried to show him: to be completely engrossed in something.

â€œWriting isnâ€™t just describing visualsâ€¦ itâ€™s everything.â€ She spoke with that same tone of passion she had when they first met, â€œAn imagination needs to be erratic, chaotic, with terrifying and boundless freedom to conceive something.â€

â€œIs that why you were always so quick with everything today?â€

She thought for a moment and then laughed, â€œSure, letâ€™s go with that.â€

Both of them were laughing, but now the tone of their voices lacked that energy and enthusiasm of earlier, it possessed a somber tone. Because they knew, with everything they had done today and with the evening itching closer, it was time for farewell.

â€œUhâ€¦ hey.â€

â€œHeyâ€¦â€

They spoke at the same time. But they werenâ€™t surprised. They still had things to say, yet they were left gazing at each other.

ã€ŒMaybeâ€¦ã€

Since they were already near his houseâ€¦

ã€ŒMaybeâ€¦ã€

Zachary moved closer to Lauren, but she instinctively turned back.

â€œOh!â€ He realized his mistake and returned to his position, â€œI thought maybe youâ€™d want to enter the mansion. We could talk about our stories too, I donâ€™t know much about yours. Maybe we could give each other tips.â€

â€œOh no, itâ€™s getting late, and Iâ€™d hate to impose.â€ Lauren gave off an awkward smile and rubbed the back of her head, â€œB-Besides, we shouldnâ€™t be so eager like this,â€ her voice turned back to the usual tone, and then she placed her finger on her lips, â€œWe should keep them a secret till after the competition.â€

He couldnâ€™t quite understand her reasoning, but he went along with it.

â€œBut we didnâ€™t even submit anything yet.â€

â€œOh we will,â€ she winked, â€œYou better get ready for the weekend, itâ€™s the deadline for submissions. And weâ€™re meeting Myung if you havenâ€™t forgotten.â€

ã€ŒThatâ€™s right!ã€

It felt as if Zachary was hit with a reality check. This one day of wonders had caused him to drift off far away from his dream than intended.

But now, he was reminded of his priorities, and with a new perspective at that.

And then he remembered that his story was quite gloomy, all things considered. It was never going to be a perfect fit with how his thoughts were now. However, he did not feel like he was in peril. Instead, he had never felt such a surge of confidence overwhelm him like that before.

He was going to make a new story.

With a few days left till the meeting with Myung and one chance to submit, he was going to write something new. It was going to be challenging. But he was still going to write it. He had to prove his worth as an author. He was going to gain Myungâ€™s recognition. He had to, after all. He had a dream to fulfill.

â€œYou look pretty excited all of a sudden,â€ Lauren smirked.

He remembered her part in all of this, and he could not be more thankful for meeting her and opening up his world.

ã€ŒWe have a dream to fulfill.ã€

â€œI mean, who wouldnâ€™t? Weâ€™re meeting Myung. We have to be in tip-top shape no matter what. You better be ready, Lauren.â€ He raised his arm and pointed his finger to the sky, â€œWeâ€™re going to change the world!â€

Lauren was surprised by his bizarre pose but ultimately found it endearing, causing her to let out a warm chuckle. It was clear that her influence had rubbed off on him a little too much, yet it all came as a benefit in the end.

â€œWeâ€™re meeting Myung! Weâ€™re going to change the world!â€ She stretched both her arms to the front, joining in on Zachary with the weird poses.

They just needed a few more people with them, to wear colorful space armor made of spandex, and their act would be officially complete.

After raising their spirits up, they waved back at each other with a smile as Lauren walked down the street. The scene looked awfully familiar to the one from the day before, except instead of being left with confusion and gloom, Zachary was now confident in himself.

He was going to write that story.

He was going to join the competition.

He was going to meet his idol.

He was going to meet Myung.

The two of them spoke together as if Zachary was but a stand-in happening to be there. Multiple thoughts went through his head, the kind that he had desperately tried to push away after so long. But he knew better than to succumb to his ridiculous thoughts like always this time.

ã€ŒNo no, stop being a brainless idiot and leave me alone. That boyâ€™s just a friend.ã€

â€œBy the way, Iâ€™m glad I saw you now," Lauren smiled, "Did you manage to fix my watch?â€

â€œWell no...," the boy scratched his chin with an embarrassed face, "But I did give it to a friend of mine who managed to fix it. She just gave it to me today, as a matter of fact."

"Oh... she...?" Her smile faded for a second, â€œThat's good.â€

After being done with delivering the good news to her, the boy waved at Zachary. â€œHey there!â€

It seemed the boy was not just a halfwit who lacked manners and thought itâ€™d be prudish only to talk to Lauren without acknowledging Zacharyâ€™s existence.

However, it was Zachary himself who lacked the courage to speak up. He came to the realization that he was completely alright with being ignored. To his luck, Lauren was still caught up with her own matter.

â€œDo you have it with you right now?â€ She interrupted.

â€œOh, no actually, but I left it in my bag. I was heading to the gym right after hanging those flyers, they need me for something,â€ he pointed at the flyers on the bulletin board right beside the trophy shelf, â€œBut then I spotted you and thought Iâ€™d do a quick stop to notify you. I can give it to you after school though.â€

â€œWait, you're helping out with that stuff?! That's not like you at all, heh.â€

â€œYeah, my friend dragged me into it â€” she has an addiction to running errands," the boy chuckled, "It's not that bad actually. Better than doing nothing.â€

Lauren smiled before glancing at Zachary with a slight firm look, urging him to join in on the conversation. She, of all people, understood him well, despite knowing him for a short period so far. But he felt fine being stuck to the expression game with her at that moment, and so he replied back with an oafish expression, raising both his shoulders upwards to signify his distress on what to do exactly.

Naturally, the boy caught wind of their little game, and he knew better than to stick around. â€œWell, I better get going then. Iâ€™ll meet up with you later?â€

â€œUm, s-sure!â€ Lauren smiled and waved at him.

The boy paid no heed to Zachary and walked away.

ã€ŒFinally!ã€

Just as he was completely out of their sight, Zachary immediately jumped to the question. â€œWho was that guy?â€

â€œYeong-Gi! He's an old friend!" Lauren happily responded.

â€œUh huhâ€¦â€ He gave her a look of displeasure.

"He was the winner of last year's writing competition at school."

â€œSo he's a writer?! No wonder heâ€™s so optimistic.â€

Oddly enough, two students passed right beside them as they were running the halls with costumes on.

Zachary and Lauren turned their heads back at each other, with estranged looks at the scene they had just witnessed. It looked like a lot of people already had the holiday spirit in them â€” to the extent of just wreaking havoc like children.

â€œNot as optimistic as everyone else as you can see,â€ he said as he scoffed.

Will all worries fade away if he adapted to the same mentality as everyone else? He wondered. Perhaps their eyes observed the world that he longed for. Thinking about that was enough to wear him down further on how he was missing something that seemed so magnificent to the others.

ã€ŒBut Iâ€™m not alone.ã€

â€œHeyâ€¦â€ Lauren placed her hand on his shoulder. Her face carried a warm look of content, but then she wrinkled her eyes and her lips opened, revealing her sparkling teeth, causing her face to beam with joy. â€œMaybe all we need right now is a little bit of that optimism!â€

An indication of reassurance, that was what this was.

This girl had enchanted him a long time ago. Nothing she would ever do could rile him up. Everything about her eased his mind. It was amazing how close theyâ€™ve gotten and come to understand one another over one shared interest. One interest sparked this adventure.

ã€ŒAnd yetâ€¦ã€

â€œHere!â€ She reached for her pocket and dropped a gold coin into his palm.

It was the same gold coin from the other day, decorated with the same design as the hanging man. The fact that she had it on her at that moment greatly bewildered Zachary.

â€œYou carry that around everywhere?â€ He was astonished.

â€œYeah, itâ€™s my good-luck coin.â€

â€œWhy are you giving it to me?â€

â€œI just told you, itâ€™s my good-luck coin. Soâ€¦ you know, good luck!â€

She pushed herself away from him and walked backwards.

â€œKeep it with you till the results come out. Youâ€™ll need it!â€ She winked and formed a finger gun before pointing it at him. â€œCatch you on the flipside.â€

And like that, she left just as she came. Sudden farewells from her were not much of a surprise anymore. She was the type of person who would get straight to the topic to get their point across and then be done with it.

Yet still, it left sombreness in Zacharyâ€™s heart.

â€œRightâ€¦â€ He smiled, although that smile conveyed ambivalence rather than joy.

He wished those short moments with each other would prolong, he wished for it ever since that day they went out to the Old Pier. That day still remained as the longest he had spent with her, and nothing ever came close to it once again. It was as if she had given him a forbidden fruit that he completely devoured and then stripped it away from him when he desired more.

ã€ŒYouâ€™re really cruel, you know that.ã€

A sigh escaped his breath, followed by a smile.

Despite everything, they were still going to be together. Their path was merely starting.

There was still hope.

Zachary stood.

He stood there â€” a week after that bizarre occurrence at school â€” right in front of the scoreboard. His body stiffened. His skin crawled. His legs nestled like logs. His chest barely shuddered. His mouth quivered, and his lips were dry. His toneless eyes gawked. There wasnâ€™t an ounce of life within him.

The results were out.

â€œ...â€

ã€MELANVALE WRITING CONTEST SCORE SHEETã€‘

ã€#1 - Lauren Cherith : 208/210ã€‘

ã€#2 - Anju Tilden : 184/210ã€‘

ã€#3 - Yeong-gi Baek : 179/210ã€‘

â€œIâ€¦ I won?!â€ Lauren gasped.

But her voice immediately faded away, Zachary was fixated on something else. His eyes spiraled up and down, left and right, scrutinizing the entire list that consisted of all contestantsâ€™ scores.

ã€ŒZachary Ashworthâ€¦ã€

In his mind, he constantly recited his name, waiting for the moment his eyes would lock onto it.

ã€ŒZachary Ashworthâ€¦ã€

The list went on and seemed like it was never-ending. He was already past the fifties and into the seventies.

ã€ŒZachary Ashworthâ€¦ã€

And thenâ€¦ the list ended.

Out of three hundred contestants, only a hundred of them were listed on the scoreboard. Two hundred people, with dreams and stories to tell, were completely unaccounted for â€” not even an honorable mention for some at the bottom. Two hundred kids were left in the mud, including Zachary Ashworth.

Not a glimpse of emotion dwelled within him. He could do nothing but acknowledge the facts, the cruel fact that anyone like him would break down for.

Lauren had won. Zachary was forgotten.

â€œT-This is really my name?! Itâ€™s unbelievable!!! Iâ€™m in first place! I won, I won, I won, I won,â€ Lauren cried with joy.

Her striking accomplishment had rendered her blind to her surroundings. She was still struggling with the fact that she had come out on top of everyone else. By winning the contest, not only will she get her story officially published, but she would be granted the chance at writing a full novel with the help of a publishing company, and possibly a helping hand from her idol, Myung. This was her great chance to become an actual author.

However, she wasnâ€™t the only one thinking about the possibilities.

Zachary shivered at those thoughts. All those awards, those opportunities that were going to be granted to his friend, things that he desperately wished for and worked hard to get, he wasnâ€™t getting even a taste of it.

He and his story were thrown in the trash.

When Lauren calmed down and came to the other realization that Zachary wasnâ€™t anywhere on the list, she placed her hand on her mouth in shock.

â€œ(Oh? Oh no, oh my godâ€¦,)â€ She spoke under her breath.

Even with her victory, she worried for her friend.

â€œZachâ€¦ Iâ€¦,â€ she tried to find the words. For the first time in her life, she felt that she lacked the words to offer comfort, â€œIâ€™m so sorryâ€¦ I didnâ€™tâ€¦â€

She tried to place her hand on his back to ease his tension.

But Zachary turned and knocked her hand away with the back of his hand.

The irises in his eyes had shrunk to a terrible extent. Tears were dropping.

Lauren was equally shocked from that push, but she tried to understand his grief, â€œListen, I know we made a promise. But I have no hand in this and you know it. I understand what youâ€™re going through. You wereâ€”â€

Her words then came to a halt, and instead something else came out.

â€œgÃ¹Ã° agdo oÃ°deox tiihot oÃ¾Ã¾ahd onhpÃ²â€

It was back.

The noise was back.

Of course, it was back. It had been slowly growing ever since the meeting.

Zachary felt the world around him spin. His vision had become distorted. The noise was crawling back into his sight.

It was covering her.

The noise was covering her, the girl that took his hand and promised of a road they could together. But now she was running, slipping away, and he couldnâ€™t keep up with her. In reality, however, he was shunning her out.

ã€ŒNo, shut up, you worthless dumbass.ã€

He screamed back at his thoughts in his mind.

Nothing had changed, he hasnâ€™t changed. Every time that fact would come crashing down on him, he would try to avoid it, but now it was right in his face. He had to face it. He had always been nobody special, that was who Zachary Ashworth was. Why should he be mad now? Why should he be mad about something that he knew was inevitable?

ã€ŒIâ€™m worse than a pile of trash.ã€

It was disgusting, his mind was disgusting, he was disgusting. He believed he should be happy for his friend. She had done so much for him, but he was the one that brought himself down. She was a star that tried to light his path, but he cowered away in the darkness. He had no place in that bright-colored sky.

There was no place for someone whose heart burned with envy for those he once trusted.

â€œIpiatesâ€¦â€

Laurenâ€™s voice echoed again. There were no words to be understood.

ã€ŒIâ€™m worthless.ã€

Coming with this conclusion, and realizing what he was truly like, he raised his fist and punched himself on the face. It hurt him, but he believed it should have hurt him more, he deserved worse.

Lauren backed away. However, he couldnâ€™t see her face, he didnâ€™t know what look she had on. Was she scared? Was she shocked? Was she smiling?

ã€ŒNo!ã€

Gathering control of his surroundings, Zachary picked up his feet and dashed out of the place, running away from everything.

He had to run away. There was no place for him here.

Into the outside he went, the sky was clouded. Rain dropped down on the streets vigorously, yet he kept running.

He ranâ€¦

...and ranâ€¦

...slippedâ€¦

...stood back upâ€¦

â€¦and then ran againâ€¦

Somehow, this all seemed familiar to him.

And of course, why wouldnâ€™t it?

This was the same thing he did the first day he met Lauren and spoke with her. He ran away that day through the streets deep in the rain. However, it was still different.

That day, he returned back to her with hope.

But nowâ€¦

If he returned back to her now, then he would be clinging onto false hope, onto a lie that he has been telling to himself over and over.

ã€ŒNothingâ€™s changed. Iâ€™m still that hopeless idiot.ã€

No matter how far he thought he had come, he was still at the bottom of the pit. There was no place for a change in him. Change went against his nature. It was why he felt uncomfortable at times, why he struggled, why he believed it was all a dream. Because that was all it wasâ€¦ a false dream.

Zachary stood out in the rain, drowning in hopelessness.

â€œFor onceâ€¦ just for once!â€

He wondered if the droplets dripping down his cheeks were his tears or if that was simply just the rain doing its magic and sorrow for him.

â€œI want to want! I want to do something for myself!â€

He lacked the luxury to cry.

â€œ...â€

He walked again, lost in his thoughts.

ã€ŒIâ€¦ã€

â€œGet out of the way!â€

All of a sudden, a voice screamed into his ear, the only voice that still carried words somehow. But before he could turn around and react, he felt a hand touch him on the back and push him away.

However, the push was too late. There was no escaping the inevitable.

And that was when he realized he had walked right into the middle of the street.

He had been so caught up in his own stupid thoughts that he failed to notice his surroundings. In the end, it was him and his bleak mind that led to his demise.

A huge, bright light emerged, approaching both him and the one who pushed him at high speed, followed by a loud screech.

ã€ŒSo this is the endâ€¦ã€

*CRASH*

That was the last thing Zachary Ashworth sawâ€¦ light.

ã€ŒFinallyâ€¦ã€

fable /ËˆfeÉªb(É™)l/

a story about supernatural or extraordinary persons or incidents.

ã€ŒOneâ€¦ã€

ã€ŒTwoâ€¦ã€

Once a desolate land, with crimson dust coating the wind to the mountains that outreached the ether, was now riddled with chaos. Unimaginable chaos; the chaos of a thousand-year war. It was a battlefield of endless slaughter. Mountains of bodies were forming everywhere, yet the warriors never stopped moving forward.

Two sides of the world, fighting at witsâ€™ end.

ã€ŒOneâ€¦ã€

ã€ŒTwoâ€¦ã€

Knights clashed their swords in the midst of the field. Archers stood by from afar as they shot their arrows. Lancers left their horses to blissful death. Monsters howled in rage at their fallen. Yet one could not tell who was the enemy.

In a world of great fiction, it would be a tale as old as time. Humans against monsters. Good against evil. But this was not a piece of fiction.

This was realityâ€¦ and reality never made sense.

Everyone was out for their own skin, even the beasts, who were not so mindless as a yarn in a tavern would deem them.

ã€ŒOneâ€¦ã€

ã€ŒTwoâ€¦ã€

If monsters were to be named, it would surely not be the beasts forced to survive, and not the humans like some tales claim to defy a commonerâ€™s expectations. The true monsters were those in the beyond. The arbiters that orchestrated this cruel fate upon a beautiful world. God created everything, but everything sought to destroy itself.

This was but a twisted belief in the eyes of the swordsman, calmly treading the battlefield on his horse like a watcher from beyond. Unseen and unscathed.

It wasnâ€™t that he was truly unseen. With a suit of armor darker than black, a face covered under the hood, and a greatsword that has seen a million battles, this swordsman was to be left alone. No one dared to fend off his threatening aura. He was a beast of darkness disguised in human flesh, cursed forever within to walk the path of the moon.

ã€ŒOneâ€¦ã€

ã€ŒTwoâ€¦ã€

In his thoughts, he counted. No more than twice each time he passed a certain distance. What was it that he counted? The number of soldiers who were struck down? Perhaps the time it took for a beast to devour one whole? Or anything that his eyes gazed upon in the battlefield? No one knew.

Nevertheless, the battle moved and he traveled across like a ghost.

The wind was starting to catch up and whistle even as the warriors persisted. This was the fate of those who battled for the strongest. Of course, there were some more who strived to achieve peace in war: a war to end all wars. But such fantasy did not exist here.

ã€ŒOneâ€¦ã€

Just as the swordsman with the giant greatsword began counting again, his thought process was interrupted as he came to a halt. Among the crowds and weapons blocking the clear view, covered by smog, stood a great and broad figure. Normally one would suspect it for a beast, but that was far from the truth. It was human, but to paint him as one like any other would be nothing but a poor jest.

â€œSoukenâ€¦,â€ uttered the swordsman.

Cladded in armor of great protection, the giant man soon shared his gaze with the swordsman. He could not help but salivate at this chance encounter once again.

He knew him. And the swordsman knew him as well.

Other soldiers rushed in and attempted to slice that man open, but he would take their life away like he did a fly. It was strange how simpletons like them would risk their life away for that man but not the swordsman who seemed much easier to clash with due to his smaller figure.

However, that did not mean the swordsman lacked any height at all. The moment he stepped down his horse, he was still reaching half the height he was at when on top of it. He towered over most of the warriors nearby. But he did not care, for his target, his mission, was that man, who towered over him as much as he did for others, the berserker.

They stood at an impasse before even starting. The berserker was sure to take down the swordsman in one blow from his mace. But the swordsman was calculating a similar method, counting not only the time it would take for his opponent to draw out his open but how much it would take to land a hit. The berserker was quite strong so even a weapon as heavy as mace would be no problem to swing in a second. However, what he was flawed at, the swordsman excelled.

There was one thing for sure to set this battle: it was a matter of speed.

The swordsman reached for his greatsword. But the berserker had already drawn first blood â€” or at least, he thought he would.

Closing the distance between him and the swordsman, the berserker inched closer with his grip on his mace in the air, ready to strike. And as he didâ€¦

ã€ŒOneâ€¦ã€

In a flash, the swordsman moved aside, dodging the attack completely. But the berserker was already on the move for another attack. Despite his size, he was light on his feet and quick with his blows. The mace was already swinging the swordsman's way, who was yet to draw out his sword.

â€œShoulda brought a knife cutter, ye bastard!â€ Shouted the berserker.

ã€ŒTwoâ€¦ã€

With a swift motion, the swordsman ducked and rolled out of the maceâ€™s away, all in a second.

â€œW-What?!â€ Cried the berserker in confusion.

If he could cut back on his attack, he would, but he had put everything into that swing that he could not stop before finishing it. It would take a whole two seconds to return back to form. Sure enough, one second had passed and his swing was slowing down. He quickly thought of swinging it back after the next second to the swordsmanâ€™s direction. But as he looked over, he could not comprehend what was before him in such a short time.

Not only was the swordsman standing on his feet with his greatsword fully unsheathed, he got off his feet in less than a second and went in for a strike. He did not cry for battle. He was not angry. He was silent the entire fight through.

*SLICE*

True to his reaction a second ago, the berserker was too late to comprehend what happened to him. The greatsword, that accursed sword, was struck right directly into his heart, piercing through his once-great armor.

There was no reaction on the swordsmanâ€™s face, who the man could see now from being so close to him. No expression of victory. Just a solemn look of death.

â€œThe Lord of the Owls has fallenâ€¦â€

It was done. That lone battle among the war was over.

The swordsman took out his greatsword before the man that was once a berserker fell to his knees and then landed on the ground, leaving a lifeless husk on the ground in the process.

â€œMay the sands of time and the tower of souls pray for your bygone flesh,â€ the swordsman mumbled to himself, hoping his words would reach the soul of his dead opponent, â€œElse youâ€™ll drown in a sea of bane.â€

The swordsman swung his sword aside to clean off the blood before sheathing it on his back.

The war was still going like nothing ever happened. After all, nothing really happened. It only took five seconds to start and finish the fight with ease. There was nothing of note here that would be visible to the naked eye.

The swordsman sighed and looked up at the sky that was barely visible from the dust. But even then, the moonâ€™s light shined like never before. It was beautiful to a point that it was haunting.

However, the swordsman did not mind. He admired it.

He remembered the words a hanged man once said to him.

â€œA wish for faint light. A wish for great blight. By the by, do you crave desire? Dream of an elusive age? The moon will grant all should the champions fall.â€

Once again, the dark knight had slaughtered another prey.

What is true death?

One could have so many hopes and dreams, and be entirely oblivious to the concept of death before their life is suddenly snatched away at a momentâ€™s notice.

If this was a world of fantasy; if it were the fanciful world of a reclusive loner deprived of any imagination, then one would die with ease in their heart, knowing full well their wasted lives will be revived in a new world to their liking that would make something out of them, make them new people.

For he was still far from death.

Opening his eyes as best he could, which felt like they hadn't been opened in years from how dry they were â€” any more and heâ€™d feel his eye sockets being pulled out â€” Zachary Ashworth was met with a scene of faint light.

Nothing out of the ordinary thus far.

Yet here he was, sitting on a bed in a hospital, recovering from whatever injuries had sprung up in his body.

â€œOh?! M-Mr. Ashworth?! Youâ€™re awake?!â€

A voice, unfamiliar to his ears, echoed in the place.

Still in his dizzy and half-conscious state, he tried to focus on what the voice said. It didnâ€™t matter who was there, it mattered that someone was there. Someone could tell him what happened after the accident, and that was all he needed at the moment.

â€œWhatâ€¦â€ He mustered up all his strength and tried to clear his sore throat, â€œWhat happened?â€

Gathering up all his strength, he tilted his head slightly to the left, toward the direction the voice came from. Sure enough, there was someone standing beside him. He was tall and coated in a lab coat. It was no doubt a doctor. Surrounding him were a few nurses with looks of distress and astonishment on their faces.

â€œUmâ€¦,â€ the doctor seemed to have a look of surprise and confusion plastered on his face, â€œYou were involved in a truck accident. B-Butâ€¦ it seems like youâ€™re okayâ€¦,â€ he turned to the nurse beside him, â€œGo get Dr. Geller, now! His patientâ€™s awake.â€

The nurse immediately rushed out of the room.

Something seemed off about the doctor, Zachary could feel it, even in his dizzy state. The doctorâ€™s words did not seem like ones that would come out of a professional one. Usually, theyâ€™d explain his situation a little bit clearer and shed some light on his condition from a medical aspect. Yet, this doctor seemed unprepared, like he hadnâ€™t expected a patientâ€™s awakening.

â€œZach!â€

There was a voice, someone, calling out his name, seemingly coming from the outside. It sounded familiar, howeverâ€¦ too familiar for his own comfort. He knew who it was calling out to him, but he wished they werenâ€™t.

And then his suspicion was confirmed when she rushed in.

Right at the doorway stood the girl that he had once shared a promise with, that same girl that he had rejected, that same girl that had caused him to run away and find himself in this sorry situation. It was Lauren Cherith.

Zacharyâ€™s eyes widened in shock. He could see her face now.

There were tears in her eyes as she smiled, it was clear she was happy that he was alive. â€œZach! Youâ€™reâ€”â€

But Zachary did not care.

He slowly turned his head to the other side, averting his gaze from Laurenâ€™s, and looked at the window â€” he didnâ€™t want to face her after everything that happened.

â€œZ-Zachâ€¦?!â€

â€œMiss, Iâ€™ll have to ask you to leave for now.â€ Another nurse, different from the one that left, stepped in front of Lauren and attempted to push her out of the room.

â€œW-Wait, I know him. Iâ€™m the one thatâ€™s been hereâ€”â€

â€œThe patientâ€™s not ready for visits at the moment.â€

With that, Lauren was forced out of the room and was gone.

Yet everything still felt like it was in disarray. Zachary could hear noise from the people around him. Everyone was rushing to do whatever task they were required to do. It was as if his awakening had caused a great commotion. Why were there so many nurses coming in and out of the room?

â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™re quite confused, Mr. Ashworth,â€ said the doctor.

There was only one thing on Zacharyâ€™s mind at the moment.

â€œHowâ€¦,â€ he let out a grunt as he turned back, â€œHow long have I beenâ€¦ how long have I been out?â€

The doctor turned aside and let out a deep sigh, â€œOne uhâ€¦ It's been one day since the accident.â€

â€œWhaâ€¦â€ Zachary would almost laugh if he could.

There was no way he would have woken a day right after the accident had happened, especially with the injuries he would have sustained. A person involved in an accident like this would regain their consciousness, at the least, one or two weeks after.

It was no lie, just a pure stroke of a miracle.

According to what the doctor who oversaw Zacharyâ€™s condition said, he had been in a truck accident with another individual that tried to save his life. No one simply just wakes up from an accident the following day like theyâ€™d wake up from a good nightâ€™s sleep.

This didnâ€™t grab a reaction from Zachary though.

There was something else in his mind that he kept thinking about that bothered him greatly. It wasnâ€™t a question about why he was still alive, or if he was contemplating the reality that he might be stuck in a wheelchair from now on.

ã€ŒWhy can I listen?ã€

For many years, he had been able to â€œshunâ€ people he desired nothing from. If they were avoidable, they were just noise. He hated it as much as he favored it. It brought him into his own little world where he could listen to just himself. Naturally, everyone in the world became â€œnoiseâ€ to him, their words were incoherent, and their faces were unclear. Only a noticeable few were free of that, like Lauren, who broke through his shell once.

But nowâ€¦ there were no longer particular individuals he could listen to, he could listen to everyone. The noise was entirely gone, and he couldnâ€™t revert it back. He was able to even listen to Lauren, the last one he had shunned out.

ã€ŒLaurenâ€¦ã€

She was probably still outside, worried about him.

When he asked the nurse who was out waiting for him, he found out his family was nowhere to be found, despite them immediately covering the bills for his treatment. Lauren was most likely the only one that came for him. Only she was waiting for him, only she truly cared for him, yet he still did not want to meet her. He didnâ€™t want to see her, especially now that he could no longer hear the noise.

At that moment, he heard the door open. There was a hand slipping in from the outside and then proceeded to knock on the door. A second later, someone leaned their head in to take a look. He knew who it was.

It was Lauren.

â€œS-Sorry, if this isnâ€™t the right time,â€ she stepped inside with an apologetic smile on her face before closing the door behind her.

One look at her and Zachary could tell how worried she was about him. Her face was not in the best shape, she looked like she was suffering from a little bit of fatigue, even her previously sparkling eyes seemed to be desperate for sleep.

But he didnâ€™t care and so, he looked away.

She stayed in her place, keeping quite the distance between him and her, â€œI uhâ€¦ Iâ€™mâ€¦ glad to see youâ€™re fine,â€ her voice and words carried a tinge of sympathy, â€œA-At least you seem toâ€¦â€

â€œYeah, Iâ€™m fine alrightâ€¦,â€ he scoffed, â€œFor a guy who canâ€™t feel his legs.â€

ã€ŒJust leave me be.ã€

He didnâ€™t particularly hold her at fault for what happened to him. But it was hard for him to look at her, to stay with her, to talk with her. There was no meaning to their interactions now. Her presence would only hurt him, and his offensive attitude would only hurt her.

â€œListen umâ€¦,â€ she struggled to find the words, â€œTheyâ€¦ they called meâ€¦ yesterday after I left. Theâ€¦ the contest committee andâ€”â€

â€œI donâ€™t wanna talk about it. I donâ€™t wanna talk about anything, just get out of here!â€ He turned and almost snapped at her.

Laurenâ€™s smile was long gone, and in its stead, was pure shock and sorrow. Any moment now and tears might drop from her eyes. That was exactly the kind of thing Zachary wanted to avoid, but then again, when did anything ever work his way?

â€œNo,â€ she wasnâ€™t going to give up, â€œYou gotta listen toâ€”â€

â€œZachary Ashworrrrrth!!!â€

A voice screamed from the outside, stunning both Zachary and Lauren at the same time and putting their conversation at an indefinite stop. Lauren soon turned from sorrow to confusion on who was calling out to him in that manner. However, Zachary knew who it was. It had been long since he had heard it, but he knew that voice very well.

Not a second later, and the owner of that voice burst into the room with madness. Sure enough, the one standing at the doorway with pure rage in her eyes was none other than his mother.

ã€ŒOf all peopleâ€¦ã€

It was clear from her appearance that it had been a long time since she stepped out of the mansion. Even after seeing her son in his current condition, her eyes were still seething with hatred. Her hair was in a dire state as if it hadn't been touched in years. Some parts of her clothes were either torn or unclean. If one didnâ€™t know any better, she would pass for a homeless person. Zachary wished he could look at her in disgust, but at the end of it all, this person was still his mother.

Without any need for introductions, she rushed in at him as Lauren backed away from her path in surprise.

â€œYou insolent littleâ€¦,â€ she grit her teeth and spoke with anger, â€œEven after all what happened, you still didnâ€™t learn and went along with your pathetic plans, and look where it got you. Do you even understand what happened to you?â€

She threw her wrath onto him despite him already knowing the consequence of his actions, he was living in it. But she just had to rub salt on the wound, otherwise, it wouldnâ€™t be his dear mother.

â€œIâ€™ve done everything to keep you safeâ€”â€

â€œI KNOW!!!â€ Zachary snapped, â€œI knowâ€¦ I know what I did, I know everything you want to say to me so why donâ€™t you go back home instead of rubbing itâ€”â€

*SLAP*

â€œDonâ€™t. Ever. Talk. Back. To me.â€ She enunciated every word.

When he realized what had happened, he was in shock.

His mother had slapped him in the face.

Without any hesitation, she simply just slapped him. And her face was still full of anger as if she hadnâ€™t done anything yet. Yes, this was his mother, the same mother that was terrifyingly overprotective of him, the same mother that was barely tolerable in his eyes anymore, and the same mother that had gone lost in her mind. But never, in her life, did she ever lay a hand on him up until now.

ã€ŒWhaâ€¦?!ã€

Zachary felt lost. It was as if that slap had kicked him thousand times harder than it ever could have done into oblivion. He placed his hand on his cheek but then shivered back, he could feel his cheek burning, he could feel it pulsating from any slight touch.

â€œHey, what do you think youâ€™re doing?!â€ Lauren could not bear to watch the scene without interfering anymore, she grabbed onto his motherâ€™s arm and pulled her in her direction, â€œThatâ€™s your son you just hit right now! You know that?â€

â€œHow I treat my child is none of your business!â€ His mother snapped back at her, â€œAnd who in the world are you?!â€

â€œIâ€™m his friend!â€ Lauren was as equally angry as her.

â€œOh ho ho,â€ his mother laughed, â€œSo youâ€™re the little witch that got him into this mess?â€

ã€ŒOh noâ€¦ã€

The way they were talking to one another was not reassuring at all. It wonâ€™t be long till that argument would spiral out of control and someone would end up hurt.

Zachary didnâ€™t want that.

But he couldnâ€™t do anything about it, he still wasnâ€™t out of the shock from the slap. All he could do was hold his hands against his ears and slid back under the pillow. There was no noise he could hide behind anymore, he could hear and see everything he didnâ€™t want, so this was his only option in his eyes.

And then came in the saving grace.

Their argument had caused a commotion that the hospital staff had taken notice of. So naturally, a few nurses and his doctor stepped in to take both Lauren and his mother out of the room, as it was clearly affecting him.

Lauren easily complied but things werenâ€™t as easy with his mother.

â€œMaâ€™am, can you please step outside?â€ The doctor tried being polite.

â€œGet your hands off me!â€ Zacharyâ€™s mother pushed the doctor aside, â€œYou canâ€™t keep me away from my son!â€

ã€ŒJust get outâ€¦ã€

â€œMaâ€™am, you being here like this is affecting your sonâ€™s mental state,â€ said the doctor, â€œIf you continue this, his mental condition will worsen.â€

â€œMental what?! Huh?!!â€

ã€ŒJust get outâ€¦ã€

â€œMaâ€™am, can you please stepâ€¦ outside?â€ The doctorâ€™s patience was running thin, â€œOr we will force you out.â€

ã€ŒJust get outâ€¦ã€

ã€ŒJust get outâ€¦ã€

ã€ŒJust get outâ€¦ã€

ã€ŒJust get outâ€¦ã€

Before Zachary had realized, there was no one in the room.

He could still hear his mother shouting outside in the hallway, and with each shout, her voice got farther and farther. They were finally dragging her away.

It was only then that he felt relief seep back into his body.

ã€ŒDonâ€™t come backâ€¦ã€

Despite his thoughts saying otherwise, he wished she would come back. He knew that her behavior was the result of what happened to them. He knew that she had been suffering from within. He knew that in spite of her mad actions, she loved him. That was why he couldnâ€™t hate her.

She was still his mother.

â€œThe right thingâ€¦,â€ Zachary uttered.

It had been an hour since anyone entered his room, so there was only him and his thoughts alone in the room.

He remembered the time when he thought he could change, the time that he defied his thoughts and decided to go back to Lauren. He could do nothing but chuckle at how naive he was.

There was no right or wrong, that much was true, but only in a world that was completely free. However, in the reality he was living in, right and wrong were determined by the people that think they can govern their beliefs onto the world to satisfy themselves.

His mother might have been right, but who was to say she wasnâ€™t? She might have been simply projecting her own fears onto him.

Zachary sat with his torso upright on the hospital bed in the room alone. There was no one in sight and the door was closed. However, it didnâ€™t bother him somehow, and he was bothered by the fact that he wasnâ€™t bothered.

He placed both his palms on his face and deeply sighed. He had grown tired of thinking altogether.

*tick* *tick*

A strange knock came from the window. He looked over to it in surprise to find that it was closed shut and with no one in sight. Perhaps it was a tree branch, the trees were pretty close to the window, almost blocking the warm light of the sunset.

With nothing to think about and nothing to do, he turned his head back to his front and simply just sat there. His eyes were completely devoid of emotion and full of melancholy as if he wasnâ€™t quite conscious of the reality around him.

*tick* *tick*

That knock came again.

Moving to the corner of his eyes, he noticed a tree branch hanging down from the tree and was near the glass window. It seemed like the wind pushed it back and forth, so it was indeed a tree.

ã€ŒJust my luckâ€¦ã€

If the wind persisted and the branch continued to knock like that, he might not be able to sleep soundly come night.

Looking back to his front, he gazed deeply into the wall with dazed eyes.

He felt his head slowly tilt downwards as if something was pushing it to drop. Following that movement, his eyelids grew heavier.

He shut his eyesâ€¦

...but then he rolled it back up again.

And so began the spiral of him fighting against sleep and his own mind. It was strange. He desired no sleep, yet his body acted like it was tired. Maybe sleep was what was best at the moment. If it could ease his thoughts, perhaps even erase them, then it wasnâ€™t so bad.

Once again, the darkness of his eyelids covered his sightâ€¦

...and once again, he opened themâ€¦

The same empty scenery of the wall existed.

He closed his eyes. He opened his eyes. He closed his eyesâ€”

â€œ...!â€

And then he sprung his eyes wide open with fright.

The scenery was different.

A figure was floating right in front of the wall.

It hid in the shadows, only remaining as a silhouette to the eyes. The wind blew from the side, pouring leaves into the room and that was when Zachary noticed that the window had opened. With another gush of the wind, more leaves flew and made way for the light to be directed at the shadows, revealing the figure in all its glory.

It took on the shape of a human, but it was neither human nor other. A force of nature would be a befitting name for it. It was terrifyingly tall, maybe two meters or more. It looked as if it was made out of natural wood, or as if a human shape was carved out of a tree and this was the result. From the elbows to the spine, to the knees, and to the ankles, there were vines crawling all over it. Strangely colored leaves covered most of its body as if it served as its clothes or armor, there were even leaves on top of its head acting as hair. As for the face, its eyes were open, there were five of them â€” almost lining up with those of an insect â€” but there was nothing within them but a red plate of wood, otherwise no one would have thought it had eyes. It was clear from the shape and certain facial features â€” if one could call it that â€” that the being was a male, or rather took on masculine form.

It seemed to be suspended in space but a large vine hung the creature from its leg.

â€œâ€”â€

Zachary stared at the being with his mouth agape and his eyes deep in shock.

He blinked once, twice, thrice, but to no avail, the being was still there. It wasnâ€™t a statue, it was moving, breathing like an actual living being. If he could laugh, he would, but this was not a laughing matter in the least.

ã€ŒIâ€™ve gone mental!ã€

â€œYouâ€™ve endured quite the endeavor.â€ The being spoke.

It had a deep and masculine voice, equally complimenting its appearance. The voice and the manner of speaking were somewhat elegant and refined, not something one would expect from such a creature.

Zachary looked down and held his hands against his head, â€œIâ€™ve finally done itâ€¦ Iâ€™ve finally hit rock-bottom.â€

â€œWhy, what is a phoenix but ashes reborn?â€ The being spoke again.

â€œAre you the grim reaper?â€ He scoffed, â€œHere to correct my death?â€

â€œPerhaps I am, perhaps I am not. Who is to say the only truth is the only truth?â€

This must have been an illusion, there was no other way about it. It was an illusion in his mind, just like the door that moved. Somehow, it bore the look of a demonic creature yet spoke with a refined tone and sophisticated words. If that was not something straight out of Zacharyâ€™s deranged mind, then he did not know what was.

Still, a question lingered in his mind, â€œThe hellâ€¦ the hell are you?â€

Although it was hanging from that vine upside down, it lowered, or in this case, raised its torso and moved its arm across its stomach as if it was kneeling in respect. â€œI am but a figment born from imagination, from the same myths and rumors I bestow upon this world as truth. That is forever the irony of our being as Strange Men.â€

ã€ŒA figment of imaginationâ€¦ã€

Those words felt like the confirmation he needed but didnâ€™t desire.

â€œSo youâ€™re just a hallucination from my mind. I really am going crazy.â€

â€œPerhaps you see it as crazy, but Iâ€¦,â€ the being spoke before it floated across the room and got slightly closer to Zachary, â€œI believe the right term isâ€¦ enlightened! Only the enlightened, those with a vivid imagination, can see a being such as I. For I am as real as fairy tales can get it. And you, Zachary Ashworth, have vastly piqued my interest.â€

â€œThatâ€™s really not helping my case at all.â€ He tried to move away and avoid the being, but with the sorry state of his legs, he could only go so far. He closed his eyes and kept mumbling to himself. â€œ(None of this is real. None of this is real. None of this is real. This isnâ€™t real. This isnâ€™t real. This isnâ€™t real.)â€

The being reached out its hands and lowered one of its vines to touch Zacharyâ€™s face. â€œIs this not real enough for you?â€

Not much of a surprise, Zachary felt the vineâ€™s thorny strand slither across his face. It was eerie and too close for comfort, causing him to shiver. He tried his best to deny the beingâ€™s existence, even going as far as believing the touch was just being simulated from his mind.

â€œHowâ€¦? What?â€ He couldnâ€™t find the words.

â€œHave you not questioned yourself recently?â€ The being started, â€œDo you not feel anything odd going on within your life? Or something new? Things changing? People changing? And yet you, somehow, remain an unmoving cog in the machine of life. Do you not find it bizarre?â€

The first thing that came to Zacharyâ€™s mind when he heard the word â€œbizarreâ€ was the sudden surge of high spirits across town. But it didnâ€™t stop there, he thought some more of what occurred during the past weeks. The mother that killed her own children, the rumored suicides, the sudden absence of students and teachers from the school, their return, and how some parts in the gloomy town turned to festivity. All of these occurrences happened out of nowhere and yet no one batted an eye to them, because why would they? They were just under the same influence of those enchanted rumors.

This could even mean that the appearance of Hye-mi Myung, his favorite author and idol, and the whole event to do with the writing competition was mere forgery among these events. After all, why would someone like Myung come to this secluded town of all places? But there was still another question on his mind, another doubt that he wouldnâ€™t dare get out.

ã€ŒCould she be alsoâ€¦ no, donâ€™t think about it.ã€

Could all of this have been the workings of that being?

Zachary grit his teeth, he did not want to face this truth, this reality that was swarming with fantasy worse than what a reality should be.

â€œIf youâ€™re notâ€¦,â€ he didnâ€™t want to say it, but he had to, â€œIf youâ€™re not in my mind, then what are you?â€

The being narrowed its eyes in disappointment. â€œMy my, am I still puzzling even after all this time? Iâ€™m devastated, my dear writer. Mere scandalmongers recognize me from the figure alone, yet you still fail to open your eyes to me. But alas, I shall keep my identity a mystery no longer.â€ It moved away from Zachary and near the window where its vines outreached, it stood with the warm twilight illuminating behind it, giving it a mystical aura, â€œA wish for faint light. A wish for greater blight. By the by, do you crave desire?â€

ã€ŒWhere did I hear these wordsâ€¦?!ã€

Zachary widened his eyes when he came to the realization.

â€œShould you dream of an elusive age, my dear writer, then I, the Hanged Man, will be at your utmost service.â€

The Hanged Man, the creature that granted wishes in Zacharyâ€™s old story. That was the identity of the being before him. The words that spoke of him were torn straight out of the paper and turned into reality.

ã€ŒThis is a joke, right?ã€

â€œYou know, you can only play pretend for so longâ€¦,â€ said the Hanged Man.

Several hours have passed since Zacharyâ€™s world had turned upside down. It was already nearing midnight. He would try to think of it as a dream and head back to sleep. He would close his eyes and attempt to do anything that would blow that creature away, but the Hanged Man was still there.

â€œGhâ€¦,â€ Zachary sprung himself up and sat upright to face the Hanged Man, â€œSo youâ€™re from my story andâ€”â€

â€œTsk tsk, you see, my dear writer, that is where you are wrong. Iâ€™m not from your story,â€ the Hanged Man explained, â€œYou simply allowed me to take part in yours, just like everyone else who once wrote about me. Iâ€™ve existed for over five hundred years.â€

â€œFive hundred years?! Where the hell are you from?â€

â€œWhy, I came from the distant land of Neverland, what else?â€

â€œNeverland?!â€ He raised an eyebrow.

As if the Hanged Manâ€™s presence wasnâ€™t odd enough, now he was claiming to be from a mystical land, and not just any land, it was one that was brought about from pure imagination and dreams. There was no such place as a Neverland. It was only a myth stuck in fairy tales that did not exist. And yetâ€¦ the creature that identified himself as the Hanged Man was right before him.

â€œI suppose your ignorance isâ€¦ predictable,â€ the Hanged Man chuckled, â€œNeverland is the world that bridges your reality with our fables. Itâ€™s a world where the written words are enchanted, where writers like you can blossom and cultivate our fantasies into something more. Imagine a world where your ink is the root of reality. You can write anything and everything on anything anywhere at any time. A world filled with writers and authors of all kinds with the sole purpose of bettering the world with their magic.â€

The way everything was said and phrased made it sound insane and delusional, but they were coming from a man formed out of wood and leaves instead of normal skin, a man who was hanging from the ceiling at all times, no less.

Somehow, it all piqued Zacharyâ€™s interest. He was willing to indulge in this fantasy a little further, even if he was losing his mind or lost in a dream. There was, however, a question that was still on his mind.

â€œWriters like me? Authors?!â€

â€œPrecisely!â€ The Hanged Man clapped his hands together before pointing out another thing, â€œBut not any author, just those enlightened with the gift of great imagination. They wield their tools with great power to cast their magic and enchanted words everywhere.â€

â€œAnd Iâ€¦ I am one?!â€

â€œWhy else can you see me?â€

â€œOh, I donâ€™t know, perhaps Iâ€™m out of my goddamn mind.â€

As much as Zachary would like to believe the creatureâ€™s words â€” anyone would love a little fantasy in their life â€” as much as his thoughts were warning him of falling down to this insanity.

â€œStill close-minded, I see,â€ the Hanged Man inched closer to Zachary and placed the tip of his finger on his forehead, â€œHow about a short trip to the beyond?â€

With one touch from the Hanged Manâ€™s fingertips, Zachary suddenly felt himself being pushed away at an incredible speed as if something was pulling him from the back through a portal. The scenery before him changed a thousand times as if he was on a trip through the boundless space of the universe. He couldnâ€™t keep up with the rush, the flickering lights almost blinded him, and yet he was still conscious. Somehow, the Hanged Man was still right in front of him with his finger on his forehead.

And thenâ€¦ darkness.

â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³â–¼â–³

When he opened his eyes, Zachary was met with an overtop scenery of a large city at night.

The cityâ€™s architecture was odd, fantastical â€” straight out of the impossibilities of imagination. It was warmly lit by a thousand lights across its streets and buildings, giving it a tinge of gold that would sparkle the onlookers no matter where they went. There was this touch of antiquity to it, as if it was a place locked in time and yet still progressed further than ever before. Buildings were structured in a compound form, coating it with what seemed to be a Victorian ornament.

Zachary could not believe his eyes, but this was only in the beginning.

A moment later, something flew past Zachary and almost knocked him away. It was a carriage, several of them, running, or in this case, flying with giant birds at the helm. However, this wasnâ€™t all. Following those carriages, were a ton of winged mythical creatures that the words could not describe. Each one varied in size and shape, some looked humanoid, some were just right out of someoneâ€™s fever dream.

Right after them, a human passed by Zachary, who seemed to be hovering on top of gold clouds and dust that dictated his flight like there was no problem.

All of these people, airborne vehicles, and creatures were all flying towards the city.

ã€ŒFlying?!ã€

That was when reality hit Zachary.

By some miracle or another, he was floating in the air across the city. He immediately turned his head upwards to be met by the Hanged Man who was carrying him through the whole trip.

Zachary felt a shortness of breath as he panicked, â€œWhy are we in the air?!!!â€

â€œWhy, to get the best view, what else,â€ the Hanged Man replied.

They had to shout to be able to hear one another among the noise, be it the noise of the wind rushing against them, the loud cheers of the crowd down in the city, or the cries of the creatures that flew by and the flutter of their wings that made waves in the air.

â€œWhat is this place?!â€ Zachary narrowed his eyes as he struggled to see from the gushes of wind.

â€œI told you, didnâ€™t I?â€ The Hanged Man laughed, â€œNeverland. Beautiful, isnâ€™t it?â€

â€œG-Get me down, I suffer from air-sickness.â€

â€œMy dear writer, you were doing just fine a few moments ago. Just forget everything and admire the scenery.â€

â€œI said, let me down!!!â€

â€œOh well, as you wish.â€

True to his exact words, the Hanged Man let go of his arms, setting him loose in the air and leaving him to fall down to the ground.

When Zachary realized what had happened to him, he was already screaming at the top of his lungs from panic. The wind rushed against his body even harder than before from how fast he was falling. He could see the grounds of the city inching closer and closer. Blinded by fear, he immediately closed his eyes to ready himself for impact.

Butâ€¦ the impact never came.

Opening his eyes once again, he found himself back in the air above the city. Looking up, he saw the Hanged Man looking at him with a smug smile on his face.

â€œYou said â€œlet me down,â€ so I let you down, as simple as that.â€ The Hanged Man offered his excuse.

â€œNot in a goddamn literal sense!â€

As they were much closer to the city now, they were able to get a better look at it. An endless amount of people filled the concrete streets, making no path for vehicles to pass. They seemed to be celebrating something from how loud their cheers were and how boisterous they all were.

However, these people werenâ€™t just humans. There were other kinds that were never before seen in reality, and only in fiction. Some were like the humanoid flying creatures. Some seemed to be humans with certain animal features. Others were really just sentient animals. Even elves, with their well-known pointed ears, existed, and dwarfs that were shorter than by a magnificent length.

Despite that difference in race, they all danced in unison.

ã€ŒThey look so happy.ã€

It felt as if he was pulled out of reality from that little monotonous hospital room and thrown into the bright festivity of a medieval fantasy novel.

â€œWaitâ€¦â€

ã€ŒBright?!ã€

Zachary widened his eyes.

The world before him, all of it, was all bright and colorful. Not a single object or place was covered in that colorless shade he was forced to always see. This could never be real, he thought. Even in his wildest dreams, he couldnâ€™t imagine a real color within them. And yet this one, this world presented itself to him with all its shine and glory. It was amazing.

â€œThis isâ€¦â€

But before he could utter another word, the world turned dark once again.

â€œ...!â€

As the curtains of his eyelids lifted, Zachary found himself back at the hospital bed in the same colorless room. For a moment, he thought that all of that was simply a dream, that he had awoken from a long dream. But then there he was: the Hanged Man, dangling from the ceiling in front of him as he had been for the past hours.

ã€ŒB-But that worldâ€¦ã€

â€œIt wasnâ€™t real?!â€ He looked at the Hanged Man with a sorrowful expression.

â€œWhat? You really expected me to fly without my vines?â€ The Hanged Man moved along with his vines next to him, â€œBut to answer your question, yes and no. That was a scene out of my own memory and experiences. What you saw was a festival held in the very mystical land of Neverland.â€

â€œGahâ€¦!â€

Zachary rubbed his hands against his head. His thoughts were in complete disarray. That colorful world seemed so real, and yet it wasnâ€™t. Or perhaps it was, according to the Hanged Manâ€™s words. But was the Hanged Man ever really real? These were the types of questions riddling his mind.

So this was either of two things, all of it was real, or he had fallen asleep and delved deep into the depths of his dreams.

â€œBy the Thousand Lords of the Night, you are a tough nut crack,â€ the Hanged Man placed his hand on his face and then let one of his vines scratch his head for him as if he was in deep thought about another solution. And indeed, he found a solution, â€œPerhaps this ought to convince you enough.â€

He calmly lowered down a few of his vines onto the bed before moving over and removing the blanket entirely off Zachary.

â€œWait, what are you doing?â€

He felt a strange intent from the Hanged Man, but he couldnâ€™t move.

The Hanged Man then proceeded to lower more vines onto Zacharyâ€™s legs, which were both encased in large casts to cover the injuries he had received â€” despite him losing the nerves and the overall feeling of his legs. The vines slowly crawled across his legs and attempted to entangle themselves before they were wrapped entirely around both legs with force. Yet still, Zachary could feel nothing.

And thenâ€¦

â€œThere was once a young manâ€¦,â€ the Hanged Man began chanting, â€œBroken without repair, he sought to empty his mind of despair. A life of silence and solitude was all that he desired. But come the night of the moon, and soon the light of the evergreen will avert the terrible fate, for another tale awaited at the end of the gate.â€

Just as the words of the chant said over and over, the vines surrounding Zacharyâ€™s legs began to glow, and with them, his legs shone as well. It was a sight not for the words to describe â€” and not for the eyes either, Zachary felt a burning sensation in his eyes as the light came through before he shut them completely.

â€œIâ€¦ canâ€™tâ€¦,â€ Zachary finally gave his answer.

The boy gasped for all the air he could at that moment. He coughed multiple times as he placed his hand on the bed to help balance himself from losing consciousness. He felt absolute relief after escaping the clutches of death.

â€œGo on, catch your breath,â€ the man straightened his suit as he stood up, â€œThink carefully about your future, kid. If you donâ€™t want a crushed windpipe then you betterâ€¦ cooperate next time.â€

The boy seemed to be in an awful physical state, so he wasnâ€™t going anywhere â€” not with those broken legs. They left him hanging onto his life on the bed, still coughing and gasping for air, and decided to collect themselves and leave for the time being.

Walking out of the hospital room, they were met by the busy ambience of the hospitalâ€™s hallways, crawling with staff members everywhere.

The men felt somewhat relieved after they were able to leave the bizarre tension of that boyâ€™s room behind. Attempting to suffocate a kid for questioning was jarring, even for professionals like them. He was a valuable asset to them, they knew better than to be reckless like some run-of-the-mill thugs.

It was surprising how he had survived the manâ€™s grip that entire time. However, the man did not exactly want to kill him, both for the information he held and for the fact that he was a powerless kid. Even though he stared him down with the intention of taking his life if he refused to answer his questions, he still had a bit of sympathy.

But what could they do? They were men following orders. They were official watchmen sent by the military police, after all.

â€œSoâ€¦ what now?â€ One of the men wondered.

They spoke to one another as they all walked together in unison. They strolled through the hallways, breaking the crowds with their strict formation.

â€œNothing in particular. Report back to base and wait,â€ said another man, Adam, who was the one previously questioning the boy (and who seemed to be the leader among them).

Another came to his side and spoke, â€œI honestly think itâ€™s quite better this way. Trust me, somethingâ€™s off about all this. We were already crossing red lines by coming here to the boy, you know what family he comes from.â€

â€œTrue, but they seem to be pretty disconnected from one another. You saw how his mother was earlier today. Any more of what she did and they would have called for us to take her in and that certainly wouldnâ€™t have ended nicely.â€

â€œBut we canâ€™t be too hasty. You never know with chinless wonders like them, theyâ€™d be happy to rip you off for all you have if they had the chance.â€

Despite being aided by the military police, they could not do entirely as they pleased. After all, there was not a thing in this world a family of nobility could not touch. If they ever so desired, they could bring down the whole system.

That was how fractured the world had become after the war.

â€œI donâ€™t know what the chief is thinking,â€ one of them wiped the sweat off his forehead, feeling like they had almost stepped on a landmine back there.

â€œItâ€™s all that priestâ€™s doing!â€ Adam spoke with dismay.

â€œOh right, that manâ€¦ Heâ€™s from another country, correct? He certainly doesnâ€™t look like a native here.â€

â€œI heard he was trying to negotiate and establish connections here for the â€œbettermentâ€ of his country. But who in their right man comes to the ends of the fucking world for a plan of negotiation?â€ The man was irritated by just mentioning him, â€œWhy is he so interested in the town? The capital is right there, arms wide open, and heâ€™d have a better goddamn chance there than he will ever have here. Weâ€™re all trying to make the most of everything we have, but then thereâ€™s that delusional bloke.â€

â€œHeâ€™s not delusional, Micheal. Itâ€™s the will of the beyond!â€ the other man chuckled, â€œI mean you saw how he was. Heâ€™s a man of God, right? I mean come on, he wears a giant cross around his neck. What did you expect?â€

â€œI expect them to fall in the same fate as the symbol they chose to remember their lord by,â€ Adam scoffed.

â€œHeh, Iâ€™d love to see him hear you right now.â€
